{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3388087,"name":"Nolan Hergert","username":"nhergert","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nhergert/{size}/162905_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-18T04:31:07.843Z","cooked":"

We encountered a weird issue where simply having a DIO device (REV Through Bore Encoder implemented as a DutyCycleEncoder) unplugged during Rio boot is causing “No Robot Code” with no stack trace to help with debugging. So I’m looking for advice on how I might be able to help improve things, and particularly why it might be manifesting in this unintuitive way.

Other devices are failing safe when unplugged/unpowered, like the CAN buses and PhotonVision/Orange Pis.

Running on RoboRio 1. Here’s the related code: FRC_2024/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/pivot/PivotIOReal.java at 2011a70c4e0844103a067ba9025a33b2ae374f16 · AEMBOT/FRC_2024 · GitHub

Here is the startup sequence:

no_robot_code1920×1440 259 KB

Happy to try stuff out on our robot, although I’m curious if anyone else is seeing the same thing.

Your code is very likely hanging here, as getAbsoluteEncoderPosition() is probably returning 0 when the encoder is not plugged in.

github.com

AEMBOT/FRC_2024/blob/2011a70c4e0844103a067ba9025a33b2ae374f16/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/pivot/PivotIOReal.java#L81-L83


      
    
          
  1. while (getAbsoluteEncoderPosition() < 0.1 || getAbsoluteEncoderPosition() > 3) {
    2. 
          
  2.   delay(1);
    3. 
          
  3. }
    4.

You should avoid this type of unconstrained loop in startup sequences. Historical note: a similar type of issue was mentioned in the 2012 Einstein investigation report: “Team 118 identified a potential problem with their code where it would become stuck in a loop when entering hybrid mode if the robot’s gyro sensor is unplugged.”

CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"cry","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3388100,"name":"Thad House","username":"Thad_House","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-18T04:51:48.811Z","cooked":"

To slightly expand on Peter’s response (Which is very likely the root cause), the robot code flag on the DS is triggered when robotInit() completes. If robotInit() never completes, you’ll always get “No Robot Code”. But because its not a crash, theres nothing to automatically attempt to restart the program.

Yep, I’m quite sure that’s the issue. Thanks @Peter_Johnson and @Thad_House!
